channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Zumba Teacher? ‘Anti-Woke’ Cleric? 38 Candidates Line Up to Head Oxford University
item.description: The role of chancellor at the University of Oxford has been around for 800 years. This year, a particularly broad range of people have applied.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Radcliffe Camera at the University of Oxford. About 26,000 alumni have registered to vote online to elect the next chancellor.

item.title: What Joko Widodo Achieved as President
item.description: Joko Widodo rose from a slum to the presidency. But with his tenure ending, he is being accused of undermining democracy by trying to install a political dynasty.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia left office on Sunday after a decade-long tenure. He remains extremely popular but has also been polarizing.

item.title: Fighting Rages in Gaza and Lebanon, Despite Killing of Hamas Leader
item.description: Peace talks were nowhere in sight and, despite Yahya Sinwar’s death, the violence seemed only to increase, as Israel struck northern Gaza and Hezbollah fired dozens of projectiles.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Liam Stack and Alan Rappeport
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Mourning a victim of a strike in Al Shati on Saturday at a hospital in northern Gaza.

item.title: The Scandal of the Indonesian Leader’s Son and the Private Jet
item.description: It was a major blow to the Everyman image cultivated by President Joko Widodo, who stepped down on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Rin Hindryati
item.media:description: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, left, with his wife, Iriana Widodo, and son Kaesang Pangarep in Brunei in 2017.

item.title: Cuba Suffers Second Power Outage in 24 Hours, Realizing Years of Warnings
item.description: Fidel Castro once called Cuba’s power plants “prehistoric.” But the country still relies on them, contributing to the longest blackout since the collapse of its former patron, the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams
item.media:description: Walking on a street in Havana on Friday night after Cuba was hit by an island-wide blackout.

item.title: Tensions Spike in Mozambique After Killing of 2 Political Activists
item.description: Leading supporters of the top opposition presidential candidate, Venâncio Mondlane, were fatally shot in their car following an election marred by allegations of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Tavares Cebola and John Eligon
item.media:description: Venâncio Mondlane, the leading opposition candidate in Mozambique’s recent election, attended a vigil in Maputo on Saturday following the killings of his lawyer and an adviser late Friday.

item.title: Despite Sinwar’s Death, Mideast Peace May Still Be Elusive
item.description: Just about all of the actors in the region are looking for an “offramp” to the conflict, many analysts say. But Hezbollah and Hamas are talking tough, and Israel is not backing down.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The killing of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar may have opened a window to a peace agreement that would be widely welcomed, some analysts say.

item.title: Despite Israeli Bombs and Assassinations, Hezbollah Keeps Fighting
item.description: Extensive Israeli attacks have blown up Hezbollah munitions and killed many fighters and leaders, but the Lebanese militia is far from incapacitated, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral last month for Hezbollah members who were killed in the pager attacks south of Beirut. Despite its losses, Hezbollah continues to fight.

item.title: 5 Provisions in China’s Panda Contracts With U.S. Zoos
item.description: Normally confidential contracts show that U.S. zoos are accepting increasingly strict terms governing panda cams and public statements.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: The San Diego Zoo, above, received two pandas from China this summer. Carefully crafted contracts set the terms for these exchanges.

item.title: A Soldier Chose a Radical Way to Publicize Troop Fatigue: He Deserted
item.description: Serhii Hnezdilov, a Ukrainian soldier, said he wanted to draw attention to the need to discharge worn-out soldiers and replace them with fresh conscripts.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:description: Serhii Hnezdilov, a Ukrainian soldier and activist, at a court hearing in Kyiv this month after his arrest on a charge of desertion.

item.title: How Moldova’s Most Popular T.V. Host Torched Her Career With a Startling Life Choice
item.description: Natalia Morari once reported on corrupt business in Moldova. Now she has upset many by having a son with a tycoon accused of corruption, and running against the pro-West president in elections.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalia Morari in her campaign office this month in Chisinau, Moldova.

item.title: Sinwar’s Final Moments: On the Run, Hurt, Alone, but Still Defiant
item.description: Israeli forces had been steadily closing in on Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader, for weeks before he was cornered and killed in a ruined house in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Natan Odenheimer, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Israel Defense Force, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still from a video captured by an Israeli drone shows a man whom Israeli officials later identified as Yahya Sinwar shortly before he was killed.

item.title: An Alarming Glimpse Into a Future of Historic Droughts
item.description: Record dry conditions in South America have led to wildfires, power cuts and water rationing. The world’s largest river system, the Amazon, which sustains some 30 million people across eight countries, is drying up.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Ana Ionova and José María León Cabrera
item.media:description: The banks of the Amazon River this month in Colombia. Colombia’s disaster risk agency recently said the flow of the Amazon River had been reduced by up to 90 percent because of a lack of rainfall.

item.title: José Rubén Zamora Will Leave Prison After Nearly Two Years
item.description: The case against José Rubén Zamora became a sign of crumbling democracy in Guatemala and a symbol of threats against press freedom across Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Rubén Zamora, the founder and publisher of elPeriódico, as he was escorted from prison to court last year in Guatemala City.

item.title: Families of Israeli Hostages Call on Netanyahu to Reach Gaza Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: In a televised statement, family members of people held in Gaza said the death of Hamas’s leader, Yahya Sinwar, was the moment for a cease-fire and hostage deal.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: Families of hostages held in Gaza calling for a cease-fire and for the release of hostages during a protest in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Iraq Suspends the Saudi-Owned MBC Channel After Protesters Storm Office
item.description: The action came after the channel aired a report describing a number of leaders of Iranian backed armed groups as terrorists.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The license of MBC Media Group was revoked on Saturday, just hours after supporters of Iranian-backed armed groups stormed its offices.

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Israel to Scale Back Attacks in Beirut Area
item.description: Lloyd J. Austin lamented that civilian casualties during Israel’s war in Lebanon were “far too high.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: While criticizing Israel for high civilian casualties in its attacks on Lebanon, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III also blamed Hezbollah for hiding its weapons and fighters among the civilian population.

item.title: Novelty Acts
item.description: We’re so accustomed to researching, planning and curating every millisecond of our lives that we rarely stop to consider the mental cost.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Drone Hits Building Near Netanyahu’s Home in Coastal Israel
item.description: The Israeli prime minister and his wife were not home at the time of the strike, his office said. The episode highlighted the challenge drones pose to Israel’s air defenses.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Securing a road near where Israel’s government said a drone had been launched toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s house in Caesarea, Israel, on Saturday.

item.title: With Unusually Forceful Words, Canada Charges India With a Criminal Conspiracy
item.description: Canada expelled six Indian diplomats after the police said they had evidence that India used intimidation and even murder to silence its critics in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The killing of a Sikh leader, Hardeep Singh Nijjar, outside this Sikh place of worship in Surrey, British Columbia, last year inflamed tensions between India and Canada.

item.title: U.S. ‘Fusion Cells’ Assist in Israel’s Hunt for Hamas Leaders
item.description: American commandos and intelligence officers began helping Israel soon after the Oct. 7 attacks last year.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: An MQ-9 Reaper drone. U.S. Special Operations forces have flown at least six of them on missions to assist in locating hostages, monitor for signs of life and pass potential leads to the Israel Defense Forces, officials said.

item.title: Reinventing Concrete, the Ancient Roman Way
item.description: By learning the secrets of 2,000-year-old cement, researchers are trying to devise greener, more durable modern options.
item.dc:creator: Amos Zeeberg
item.media:description: The Pantheon in Rome has boasted the largest unsupported concrete dome in the world for 2,000 years.

item.title: Man Arrested in Japan After Attack on Governing Party Headquarters
item.description: An assailant tried to breach security at the office of the new prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, the police in Tokyo said.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The police investigated on Saturday after a vehicle rammed into a fence near the entrance to the prime minister’s office in Tokyo.

item.title: What Will Happen to Yahya Sinwar’s Body?
item.description: Uncertainty surrounds the fate of the Hamas leader’s corpse as experts say Israel will likely try to avoid having his resting place become a shrine.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, at a rally in 2021 in Gaza City.

item.title: Hamas Says Its Demands Are Unchanged as Biden Pushes for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: A top deputy to the killed Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar vowed that his “banner will not fall” and that the group would hold to its cease-fire conditions.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Aaron Boxerman, Bilal Shbair and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: A portrait of Yahya Sinwar was held aloft at a rally on Friday in Ramallah, in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Why Israel Targeted Yahya Sinwar
item.description: What does the killing of Yahya Sinwar, mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack, mean for Israel and Gaza? Ronen Bergman, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine who is based in Tel Aviv, explains.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Nikolay Nikolov, James Surdam, Laura Salaberry, Farah Otero-Amad and Dave Horn

item.title: Lebanon Issues Rare Criticism of Iran Over ‘Blatant Interference’
item.description: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, summoned Tehran’s envoy over reported comments by a senior Iranian official on a U.N. resolution deemed a precondition for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: “The issue of negotiating to implement international resolution 1701 is being undertaken by the Lebanese state,” Mr. Mikati said on Friday.

item.title: Drone Captures Moment of Defiance, Which Israel Says Was Sinwar’s Last
item.description: In a war often seen from far away, the footage from an Israeli drone appears to capture a moment both pivotal and personal.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler, Lauren Leatherby and Riley Mellen

item.title: Israel Destroys Nearly All of a Lebanese Village, Photos and Videos Show
item.description: About two dozen buildings were demolished in the village, which The Times identified as Mhaibib, just over a mile from Israel’s northern border.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Euan Ward

item.title: Sinwar’s Death Was a Victory for Israel. But Can the U.S. Persuade It to ‘Take the Win’?
item.description: Assassinating Yahya Sinwar was Israel’s Osama bin Laden moment. But getting a cease-fire deal done in the last three months of the Biden presidency is a much bigger reach.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the death of Yahya Sinwar on Thursday, President Biden’s hopes of a quickly assembled deal before he leaves office may be buried with the longtime terror leader.

item.title: U.N. Peacekeeping Force in Southern Lebanon Will Remain, U.N. Official Says
item.description: Israel has demanded that the force, known as UNIFIL, pull out. But all the countries contributing troops and the U.N. Security Council decided unanimously that UNIFIL should stay.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: The U.N. peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, known as UNIFIL, on patrol last week in Marjayoun, a mostly Christian area about five miles from the Israeli border.

item.title: Cuba Suffers Blackout After Power Plant Failure Near Havana
item.description: The Cuban government had just announced emergency measures to reduce electricity use — then the power went out across the entire nation.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: People waiting at a bus station on Friday in Matanzas, Cuba, following a power outage across the entire country.

item.title: A ‘New Day’? Justices Step Back, Slightly, From an Aggressive Climate Stance.
item.description: The Supreme Court’s decision to not temporarily block an E.P.A. rule this week signals ‘rising influence’ of Justice Barrett, one analyst said.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: West Virginia led the challenge to the E.P.A. rule, which would require power plants to capture greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Sinwar’s Death Highlights Israel’s Long Quest for Deterrence
item.description: Israel’s killing of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar is the latest expression of Israel’s belief that regional acceptance will be achieved only through strength.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the central Gaza Strip in January, during an escorted media tour by the military.

item.title: Italian Judges Strike Down Request to Hold Migrants in Albania
item.description: The ruling was a major blow to the conservative government’s plan to have asylum claims heard in Albania instead of Italy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A ship carrying migrants intercepted in Italian waters arriving in Shengjin, Albania, on Wednesday.

item.title: American Man Kidnapped, Taken Away on Boat in Philippines, Police Say
item.description: Four armed men shot and abducted a 26-year-old from Vermont in western Mindanao, the police said. He had been living in the area since May.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Philippine National Police Regional Office 9, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A police officer investigating in the area where Elliot Onil Eastman, an American living in the Philippines, was abducted on Thursday, according to the police.

item.title: Yes, Ambassadors Can Get Away With Murder
item.description: Diplomatic immunity is one of the oldest and most respected rules of international law.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A woman walking past the spot in Surrey, British Columbia, where Hardeep Singh Nijjar, a prominent Sikh cleric, was assassinated in 2023.

item.title: India Aids U.S., but Is Stern With Canada, Amid Murder Plot Accusations
item.description: In both cases of plans targeting Sikh separatists, suspicions of New Delhi’s involvement have arisen. That has put India in a tight diplomatic position.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: American prosecutors have accused an Indian intelligence official of orchestrating a plot to kill Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh lawyer and activist who holds U.S. and Canadian citizenship.

item.title: France Struggles to Dry Out From Flash Flooding
item.description: Heavy rainfall and swollen rivers unleashed torrents of brackish water that cut off roads, swept away cars and swamped buildings.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Cars partially submerged in a commercial zone in Givors, south of Lyon in central-eastern France, following heavy rainfall in the area on Thursday.

item.title: Why Thomas Tuchel Was the Right Choice for England. And the Wrong One, Too.
item.description: An outcry over the hiring of a German to lead England’s national team was predictable. But don’t dismiss every objection out of hand.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Is this man the right choice to be England’s manager?

item.title: Much of Ireland Is an Ecological Desert. Meet the Man Who Wants to Rewild It.
item.description: Eoghan Daltun rewilded his land in West Cork and wants more of Ireland to do the same.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eoghan Daltun turned his farm in West Cork, Ireland, into a temperate rainforest. “Give it five or 10 years and things will be very different here,” he said.

item.title: Kenya’s Deputy President, Rigathi Gachagua, Is Impeached
item.description: It’s the first impeachment under the country’s new Constitution, but some are now calling for a similar move against President William Ruto.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The National Assembly, Kenya’s lower house of Parliament. The Senate’s vote to impeach Deputy President Rigathi Gachagua followed similar proceedings in the National Assembly.

item.title: Yahya Sinwar’s Death Could Shake But Not Topple Hamas, Experts Say
item.description: Analysts call the killing of several Hamas leaders, including Yahya Sinwar, a deep blow to the Palestinian militant group, but expect it to keep fighting.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers with al Qassam Brigades, Hamas’s military wing, in Gaza City in 2011.

item.title: Biden, in Germany, Urges Unwavering Support for Ukraine
item.description: The president, in a trip to Berlin that lasted barely a day, also joined Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in expressing new optimism about the prospect for peace in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: From left, Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, President Biden, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Indicts 2 Linked to Oct. 7 Cyberattack on Israeli Warning System
item.description: The Justice Department has accused two Sudanese brothers of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure as well as preventing possibly lifesaving alerts from reaching Israelis as the Hamas attack unfolded.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment complex in Ashkelon, Israel, that was hit by rockets fired by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: The Gisele Pelicot Rape Trial Hits Painfully Close to Home in This French Town
item.description: The town of Mazan, where Gisèle Pelicot was drugged and raped by her husband and strangers, has been shaken by the revelations. “It feels a bit like it’s in our family,” one resident said.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti saying “Death to patriarchy,” on a wall in Mazan, France, where Gisèle Pelicot used to live with her husband.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The leader of Hamas is dead.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the Palestinian leader of Hamas in the Gaza Strip, at a rally in 2021.

item.title: Ukraine Draft Officers Detain Men After Concert Amid Ongoing Russia War
item.description: Men who attended the Kyiv concert of a popular rock band had their papers checked on the way out. Some were detained. Tickets to subsequent shows suddenly became available.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Draft officers and the police waited outside a Kyiv concert hall after a sold-out show by Okean Elzy, looking for men trying to dodge military service.

item.title: U.S. Charges Indian Official in New York Assassination Plot
item.description: The United States and Canada have worked together to investigate what they say is the Indian government’s campaign against Sikh separatists.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, right, and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia last month as President Biden spoke in Claymont, Del.

item.title: Hamas Leader Yahya Sinwar Was Killed After a Surprise Battlefield Encounter
item.description: Although Yahya Sinwar was a major target of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, the soldiers who killed the militant chief had not expected to run across him, Israeli officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Raja Abdulrahim, Patrick Kingsley and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar in Gaza City before the war.

item.title: Israeli Military Drone Footage Claims to Show Yahya Sinwar Shortly Before He Was Killed
item.description: The video shows a room that matches photographs obtained by The Times that show the corpse of a man closely resembling the Hamas leader.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: David Lammy, U.K. Foreign Secretary, Visits China in Bid to Reset Relations
item.description: David Lammy is set to meet China’s foreign minister in Beijing on Friday, in a trip the British government said would acknowledge “areas of contention as well as areas for cooperation.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: David Lammy speaking at the Labour Party conference last month. “Engagement with China is pragmatic and necessary to support U.K. and global interests,” he said in a statement released ahead of his visit to Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Biden Talks to Netanyahu About Sinwar’s Death and Getting to a Cease-Fire
item.description: After arriving in Berlin for previously scheduled meetings, the president said he was sending the secretary of state to Israel in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: President Biden talking with reporters in Berlin, on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The Leader of Hamas is Dead
item.description: Plus, an interview with Hugh Grant.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar in Gaza City last year.

item.title: Behind Nigeria’s Fuel Tanker Explosion, a Fatal Quest for Cheap Gasoline
item.description: More than 160 people died when an overturned fuel tanker in northern Nigeria exploded. Witnesses and relatives of victims said poverty had driven most to try to collect the spilled gas.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Auwal and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Victims of a tanker explosion receive treatment inside an ambulance at the Aminu Kano teaching hospital in Kano, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: How Israel Found and Killed Hamas Leader Yahya Sinwar in Gaza
item.description: A unit of Israeli trainee soldiers came upon Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, while on an operation in southern Gaza, defense officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud/SOPA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: In Northern Gaza, Hunger Looms Over Daily Existence
item.description: Families say they are rationing what little food they can find while living under the constant threat of Israeli bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Abu Bakr Bashir and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinians receiving vegetable patties prepared by volunteers in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, in August.

item.title: What Yahya Sinwar’s Death Could Mean for the Gaza Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The killing of Hamas’s leader may allow Israel to claim victory and agree to a cease-fire, and new Hamas leadership could be more open to compromise. But neither side is likely to immediately change course.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Families and supporters of hostages, some noting the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, demonstrated on Thursday in favor of a truce in Tel Aviv.

item.title: More Forests Are on Fire, a Big Risk in Climate Change Fight
item.description: Carbon emissions from forest fires increased more than 60 percent globally over the past two decades, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kayle Neis/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A forest fire burning northeast of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, in 2021.

item.title: Biden Prepares Quick, Rescheduled Visit to Germany, a Key Ally
item.description: The president’s hastily rescheduled trip to Berlin will last less than a day. The German government has trimmed back its celebrations accordingly.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden preparing to board Air Force One, en route to Berlin, at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Thursday.

item.title: Yahya Sinwar, Leader of Hamas, Is Dead
item.description: Mr. Sinwar climbed the ranks of the Palestinian militant group to plot the deadliest attack on Israel in its history.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, greeting the audience at the International Quds Day festival in Gaza City last year.
